content:
Tim Abbott said:

I have wanted to add a feature log for some time; we don't currently have any mechanism other than the changelog and blog posts for advertising new features.

I can't find previous conversations about this, but I do recall discussion along the lines of sending PMs, etc.
Here's how discord does it:
discord change log pop up
Are you referring to this thread? #feedback > Changelog or list of features on update
Yeah, they do a really good job with this. I would love it if someone built a similar widget and would be happy to manage the work of putting features in there.

Tim Abbott said:

Yeah, they do a really good job with this. I would love it if someone built a similar widget and would be happy to manage the work of putting features in there.

Can we just scrape the text from what you put in the blog or like a separate elaborate list of new featues with each update?

I think ideally we'd have a small file with the list of features that we embed as needed into...

  • Tim's blog updates (I suspect he would still kind of manually edit them for the actual blog entry, but maybe not)
  • our version of the Discord here's-what's-new popup
pop-up after every major update?

Vaibhav Raj Singh said:

pop-up after every major update?

We might want to be more granular for zulipchat.com, since they aren't tied to major releases, and we want to keep our paying customers happy. So I could see having two or three of these per release cycle.

If somebody wants to work on this, I think you can add a lot of value by just reading the commit logs and doing your best job of picking out four or five really cool new things from the last couple months. And then Tim can always edit them, re-format them, etc., as needed.

Steve Howell said:

Vaibhav Raj Singh said:

pop-up after every major update?

We might want to be more granular for zulipchat.com, since they aren't tied to major releases, and we want to keep our paying customers happy. So I could see having two or three of these per release cycle.

Maybe add a setting which lets the admins choose whether to show the updates every time. We can have that disabled for czo.
I know Zulip doesn't use any system like this right now, but would something like towncrier help with managing all of this?

Since we are aiming for end-users over here, I guess we could add some appealing stuff too. Not just update logs per se, but more like how updates are shown in app stores.

We worked on the valuable feedback by our users and here are the latest updates!

  • The functionality to move topics between streams has been added. Now you can easily move conversation's to the suitable stream without much hassle!
Something of this sort with a GIF example would definitely be appealing

For V1 I think https://pypi.org/project/towncrier/ might be overkill. I think the hard part here is generating the marketing copy. Serving it up in a modal should be easy. It's worth looking at their page, though, if only for inspiration on some terminology. I like how they say "news fragments," for example.

Yeah, my worldview as to how this should work is the server diffs the set of announcements with what the user last saw when deciding whether to pop up the notice, and then we mostly just have a changelog-type file that powers it.
Hrm, how would we persist which features each user has already seen? Would a tiny DB table like UserFeaturesNaggedAbout be overkill?
I call it "nagging" lovingly, by the way.

Tim Abbott said:

Yeah, my worldview as to how this should work is the server diffs the set of announcements with what the user last saw when deciding whether to pop up the notice, and then we mostly just have a changelog-type file that powers it.

Since the aim is for end-users, how about emphasising on the visual changes more? Promoting them to use the new features.
We will definitely emphasize user-facing features here.

So, django's migrations system could be a nice example of how to structure the whole system:

$ ls static/updates/*
001-initial.md
002-topic-moving.md
003-markdown-replaced-with-latex.md

And then a DB field in UserProfile: last_nagged_id as a ShortInt to store which was the last message shown.

We could leverage our markdown rendering extensions for our docs pages here, and that would keep the text readable as well.

Although... we would have to enforce rules like not editing past notices unless its fixing typos etc ourselves.
I like the migrations analogy!
It's pretty easy to enforce that sort of rule, so I'm not worried about that.
